post_text: Augusta County Public Schools is committed to educating every child for future success and providing safe and productive learning environments, every day. Hatred, racism, bias, and violence have no place in Augusta County Public Schools or our community. We maintain as paramount priorities our commitment to nondiscrimination and equality in all our programs, services and activities, and our commitment to fostering and celebrating in all our staff and students’ compassion and respect for diversity and individual merit. We are fully aware that intolerance and violence have lasting, negative impacts far beyond just those immediately involved, and particularly for our students, and we are confident, even in difficult times, that kindness, tolerance, and empathy are among the easiest qualities to model and share with our students, families, and community.

We are in the heart of flu season. Here are some tips to keep your child and our school community healthy.

• Wash hands or use hand sanitizer frequently, especially before eating and after sneezing or coughing
• Cover your mouth or nose with a tissue when you cough or cough into your elbow or sleeve.
• Develop good health habits in regard to hygiene, diet and sleep.
• Dress children appropriately for the weather.
• Make sure that the school has parent contact information during the school day
• Ill children need to stay home until fever free for 24 hours without the use of fever reducing medication.
• For vomiting and diarrhea, students should stay home until 24 hours after last vomiting/diarrhea episode.

Thanks for your help combating this cold/flu season.

Carol Cash RN, MSN
School Community Health Services Coordinator

Over the course of two days, sixth-grade students in Miss Cerminara’s history and Mr. Sullivan’s science classes were challenged to design and create a crate that would keep a tea bag dry for the longest amount of time while in the rough and icy waters of Boston Harbor.

This cross-curricular project was intended as a culminating activity for the unit on the events before the American Revolution. This particular lesson helped students create a lasting understanding of the events that led up to the Boston Tea Party. Students enjoyed working in pairs with limited resources; however, their creations and ingenuity were anything but limited!!
